ygData.subject: Cantera 1.7.0
ygData.msgSnippet: Cantera version 1.7.0 may be downloaded from sourceforge or checked out using CVS. To check out version 1.7.0 from CVS, simply add the option -r

Cantera version 1.7.0 may be downloaded from sourceforge or checked  
out using CVS.

To check out version 1.7.0 from CVS, simply add the option "-r  
Release_1_7_0" to the "cvs checkout" command.  This will always  
retrieve version 1.7.0, even after the development version moves  
beyond 1.7.0.

A unix tar.gz file is also available for download.  It may be built  
in the usual way, as described here: http://blue.caltech.edu/~dgg/ 
html/cantera-build.html.

Windows developers can get the latest Windows source version from CVS  
too. The "win32" module has also been updated to version 1.7.0.  Some  
new features for Windows are:

1. Support for sundials  All you need to do is download the sundials  
2.3 source code and place it in a directory at the same level as the  
Cantera directory; building the Cantera Visual C++ "solution" will  
automatically build sundials too (or at least those parts used by  
Cantera).

2. Enhanced and functioning C++ demo project files.  All C++ demos  
available in the unix version are now available in Windows too.   
Project files are automatically installed in the "demos/C++" folder  
in the Cantera installation directory.


General enhancements:

Version 1.7.0 should compile with few if any problems on linux,  
cygwin, Mac OS X, and Windows.  Some things that are new since  
version 1.6 are:

1. A simplified interface to Cantera's boundary value problem  
solver.  You can easily solve many different boundary value problems  
with class "BoundaryValueProblem".  See "cantera/apps/bvp" for more  
details.

2. More robust equilibrium solver.  The ChemEquil solver has been  
made much more robust.  Now it should rarely fail, even on "hard"  
problems.

3. Sensitivity analysis.  So far implemented only for reactor network  
problems.  See file "demos/python/reactors/sensitivity1.py".

4. New types of reactors:  FlowReactor, and ConstPressureReactor.  
FlowReactor simulates isentropic flow in a duct, with "time" replaced  
by "position" in the duct.  FlowReactor objects must be used alone  
and cannot be connected to other reactor types (for which time is  
really time).  ConstPressureReactor keeps the pressure constant, even  
without installing a flexible wall to do the job. In general, this  
will be more robust numerically than do-it-yourself constant-pressure  
reactors.

5. Other stuff.  Ability to modify NASA polynomial coefficients, and  
other things I have forgotten now.  Version 1.6 was a long time  
ago... if you have been updatingg regularly from CVS these features  
have been available for some time.

One thing that has not been touched is the MATLAB interface.

Let me know if there are any problems, particularly any build issues.


Dave
